document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. document.text: owing to the late prilli Wheat crops are looking well. 1 said once this spring that all of the fruit was killed, but I find that 1 spoke too fast, as there is fruit on every tree that 1 see. As a peach orchard is a thing of the past, all who are fortunate enough to have some trees are blessed, with the deli cious fxuit. We had a flood in Wreck-Island Greek, causing much damage to land aud crops. It is said to have been the biggest flood that we have had for twenty years. It washed away the bridge over Wreck-Island Creek, near here, on Carsons millpond. It did much damage to Mr. C. H. Cole mans tobacco crop, taking hill, to bacco, and all. It washed away the entire crop of- corn belonging to th iol lowing persons J. W. Stratton, Cliff. Martiu, and E. W. Moore. It did some damage to J. J. Carsons mill, washing out the underpinning. We hear of a good deal of damage all along the creek. . Mr. W. W. Wright is out again, and is able to do some work. Madam liumor says there will be a marriage in this neighborhood at at au early date. We wish the pair much happiness. We hear that a doctor is about to locate near this place We bid him welcome. This letter reached us last week, but too late for prompt pubiicaton

document.text: Howlett. D ear T imes I have been think ing of writing to you for some time but have been otherwise engaged. Now, as Uncle Sam has given us a post, office at this place, I must write and tell you how pioud we are of it it has been a long felt want. We dont have daily mail yet but hope to soon. Mr. Harry Blanks aud his best girl took a flying trip to Amhurst. Miss Emily Thornhills school has closed. Miss Elizabeth Martin is visiting her aunt, Mrs. J. W. Stratton near this place. Air. Wilbur StrattOD does not improve fast. Mr. J. J. Carson is out again and weighs 173. Mr. W. W. Wright has been very sick for the past week wih neural- Alrs. G. Zeigler, who has been at the Virginia Hospital in Richmond for several months, returned to her home in Cumberland county much improved. We hope she will be en tirely wtll soon. We are sorry to learn that Mr. Bunk Page, of Gleufall, has a very sick child. He was for many years a resident of this place. busy preparing their land for crops hope tlieyniay have a bountiful harvest. With every good wish for you, dear T imes , I will close, piomising to gall again.

document.text: N ews o f Concord. This week in Concord will be a most rare one. Mr. Polk Miller will be there at Staples Hall, Saturday night, September 28th. The hall is being arranged to ac commodate 500, and the extensive advertising assures us that we will not be disappointed. In addition to this, the Udies of the Ladies Aid Society are 4rrating in unique style a lawn party, begiucugat 4 p. m. th it day and to continue un til after the entertainmeut. Polk Millers fame is universally known, we accord ingly honor Lis presence. Mrs. W. B. Jett, after visiting relatives in Eastern Virginia return ed last week with her sister. Miss Beatrice Bryant, who will spend a brief visit in the village. Mr. W. C. Akers after spendiug a week with his family, returned to his duties on S. A. L. Railroad last Friday. Miss Emily Thornhill, of Lynch burg, is the guest of Mrs. K. W. Stratton. Mr. J. H. Steele, after facing ab sent from lailroad duties since last March with a serious spell of ill ness is again resuming dnty as fore man carpenter. Mrs. Dr. W. F. Fisher, of Alex andria, Va., the guest of Miss An nie Fisher, returned home a few days ago. Under the supervision of Mr. J. H. Steele, the Baptist church was begun last week and is soon expect ed to be under roof. We gladly en tertain this new work. Mise Jonnie Martin ie suffering severely from the eting of an in sect on her hand. Mrs. Emma Martin, after some weeks illness, is better now.

document.text: To th e V oters of Campbell. Whereas a card purporting to le signed by a number of citizens of Appomattox in reply to the address of the Executive Committee of said county appeared in the News-Herald which reflects upon this committee and each member of it, in insinua ting that the ten gentlemen wln constitute it are the tools of and con trolled by two of its members, who happeu to be the Chairman and Secretary, and in saying, that every thing also is a pure nd simple system of studied fabrication manufactured solely for electioneering purposes i misrepresent, to mislead and to de ceive and whereas we do not be lieve that the parties who signed i did so knowing what its con tent.- was or intending to reflect upon this committee or any member of it by signing a paper so utterly without regard to the truth of th, case, therefore, Be it resolved, That this com mittee reaffirms every statemeni contained in said address and vouches the truth thereof that in a meeting held this the 1st day ot November, 1899, iu which every member is present, we state that tin publication of said address was au thorized by us and we today unani mously ratify it and endorse its publication and that we do not, be lieve that the parties whose names appear on said card authorized their names to be signed thereto, but that their names were placed there without their authority. S. L. Ferguson, Chairman Jas. B. Abbitt, Secy. W. H. Ligon, J. C. Jones, A. H. Howerton, W. J. Trent, S. C. Stratton, W. C. Abbitt, J. W. Clark, A. B. Thornhill, S. J. Lee.

document.text: Stonewall Democrats Organize. An enthusiastic crowd of Demo crats met at Shearers store, Stone wall precinct, yesterday evening and organized a Stonewall, Bryan. Sewall and Flood, Free Silver Club with 39 members and elected the following officers J. S. Thornhill, President H. S. Anderson, first Vice-President S. C. Stratton, J. D. Alvis, W. S. Tay lor, H. C. Babcock, H. D. LeGrand, vice Presidents J. R. Horsley, Sec retary and C. M. Stratton, Treas urer. After perfecting the organization, the club adjourned to meet Saturday Sept. 26th, at 7 p. m. The following committees were appointed On arrangement S. E. Anderson, W. O. Shearer and Ced. E. Drinkard. To Secure Speakers S. C. Strat ton, T. H. Lewis and J. R. Horsley. There is a good deal of enthus iasm and we hope to double our members at the next meeting, as many were prevented from being present that would have joined.

document.text: Mrs. T hom as J . S tra tto n . The death of Mrs. Thomas J. Stratton occurred at her home ia Appomattox county on Tues day evening, October 9th. Mrs. Stratton had been in failing health for some months, and her death was not unexpected. The burial took place on Thursday from Hebron ohureh, of which she was a member. The servioes were conduoted by the pastor, Rev. J. M. Street. The services were simple and appropriate, consisting of a few favorite hymns of the de ceased sung by the congrega tion, and a few well chosen re marks by the pastor, oonclud ed by a prayer at the grave in Hebron cemetery. Mrs. Stratton leaves surviv ing her husband, Hon. Thomas Stratton and six children, as follows J. Ernest Stratton and Frank W. Stratton, of Lynchburg J. Albon Stratton, of Kelson T. Corbin Stratton, of Appomattox Walter Strat ton, of Washington, D. C. and Mrs. Lizzie Soott, of Bedford besides a number of grandchil dren. The deceased was about sev enty-five years of age, and had spent all of her married life in the Hebron community of Ap pomattox county. She was a conscientious Christian wo man, and left many comforting testimonials of her Christian faith, the be.st of which was reflected in her daily life in her home and among her neigh bore and friends. Her cheer ful disposition and kind spirit will not soon be forgottenv,by those who had the good for tune to know her. The death of Mrs. Stratton will be genuinely mourned. Mr. Thomas J. Stratton, who is held in honor and esteem by the people of Appomattox, and the members of his family have our sympathy in their die tress, which was evidenced by the great number present at the burial service, and their beautiful floral tributes.

Cs time was out - by -contract on last day of September. 1 let-him Know that I intended to move down and wanted to make repairs. 1 asked privilege of looking through house Mr. and. C. came down stairs and said he had a box of glass on hand which would fit the windows and if you will take it you will save me trouble.of seud-ng it back. -Ill take it, tbere is one out I have had to put iu several times saiu C. I know -I was deliberate, not fretted, or serious, took glass m my hand and Was talking. 0. followed me up anu took hold of my coat or sleeve and said, let that glass alone aqd get out of here I turned and took hold of his lapel and said, suppose you get out of here your time is out. I pressed him along towards tbe front door.

document.text: F a n u e n  Club and Roads D is cussed by Mass-Meet luff. At a largely attended mass-meet iufc  here Thrsday, T. J. Stratton was mado-ohairputg rod W. j. Trent secretary. Major J. W. Flood made the openin speech in favor of a reg ular monthly Meeting day for Un people of the Qopnty, and suggested that a bill be drawn fixing regular monthly- meeting days for the su pervisors Wad school board. This propQeftton was voted down, bnt a committee was raised for the pur- po e of devising a plan and some scheme for getting the soverigns to gether monthly. This committte is expected to report to a mass-meeting which will be bold next month. There are many advantages to be , derived from . a monthly conference of our farmers, and we would be glad to have them assemble here in the capacity of an institute or club. There will be but one more term of the old county court and some kind of permanent institution should be organized to take its plaoe. The same organization took up the road question and after much discussion it was practically decided to rpfer the whole matter to a com mittee composed of the present and new board of supervisors, the newly elected road commissioners and per haps the aid of the magistrates will pointed be sought in getting up a plan to be submitted to a mass-meeting whiob is to be called for January or Feb ruary court. The sense Of  meeting was evidently in favor of retaining the road machine, and the discussion developed the fact that the road machine had, greatly im proved the roads. There are many of otit- citizens, however, who claim that the present system does not pay enough attention to the roughplaces and it would be well for the com mittee to consider carefully this fea ture of the plan they will provide or the meeting will almost certainly amend it. It is said there are sev eral roads in Stonewall which have been neglected for years. Mr. How erton who spoke for the contract system said that  a chain is no stronger than its weakest link, nor a road no better than its worse mud- hole. Mr. Bristow in offering his motion to repeal the road law enact ed last spring Bpoke with earnestnsss to his resolution and spoke of the great advantages of the machine over the labor and contract system. Major Flood, Hon. W, H. Ligon and Dr, Bobertson addressed the meeting No vote was taken which fairly pre sented the issue between the machine and the contract system, and it looks now like the whole matter will be np again for decision at the next mass-meeting, with the chances in favor of the machine. document.text: Democratic Mass-Meeting. At a meeting held iu the Court House on Thursday last for the pur pose of nominating District officers to be voted for at the coming elect ion, May 27th, it wus moved that Dr. D. Mott Robertson be made chair mau and F. W. McKinney, secretary The county then divided up in districts and repaired to the ante-rooms, aud after some de liberation reported the foRowing nominations to the mass-meeting. OLOVE.I HILL DISTRICT. SupervisorW. H. Ligon. Con stableF. W. McKinney. . Justices W. J. Treut, W. D. Hix, U. H. Beale. Overseer poorE. E. Chism. STONE WALL DISTRICT. SupervisorS. C. Stratton. Con stableH. C. Babcock. Justices- J. W. Davidson, N. W. Owen, J. S. Thornhill OverseerG. L. Fer guson. SOUTH SIDE DISTRICT. SupervisorJ. C. Jones. Con stableA. H. Abbitt. Justices- Juo. T. Lee, Simeon Harvey, Lamech Jones. Overseer poorS. E. How erton. Themassmeeting was well-attended aud the tiominees are all good strong meu. They pledged themselves to the service of the party by accepting the nominations and will all makej an effort to get out the full vote of the party on Thursday May 27tb. The offices have been well distributed over the county and good true men selected to fill them. Now, je sore that you do your duty and each of them will be elected.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. G OBrien, S L. Ferguson, Jr., J. H. OBrien, W. B. Caldyell, F. L. Murphy, E. VR-y Smith, Andrew Wingfield, H. C. Pul iam, Uoel Flood, Don Moses, John T. Cole, J. W. Caw son, John A. Iweedy, R. W. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: All thing work together for good to them that love God. Romans 828. Mr. John Ewers came home from hospital Saturday. Mrs. W. E. Bondurant, J r and Mr. Bert Stratton are in the hospital now. Do hope they get on well and will soon be home. Mrs. Vara Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. R. W. Webb visited Mrs. Elsie Caldwell and Mr. and Mrs. I. B. Wheeler Friday. What a pleasant surprise. Mr. and Mrs. I. B. Wheeler visited Mrs. Hazel Gillaspie last week. Mrs. Hazel Gillaspie went to Big Island to visit her sister-in- law Friday. Sunday Mr. and Mrs. I. B Wheeler had a birthday dinner for their grandson, Tommy Wheeler. Those present were Mr. and Mrs. Ben Wheeler and David. Mr. and Mrs. H. B. Gordon, of Richmond. All wished him many more happy days. Mrs. C. Ti Roach spent Saturday night with her father Mr. J. 0 . Davidson and Mr. Crawford Davidson. Mrs. Annie Horsley is still improving at The Guggenheim er Nursing Home Lynchburg Va! after having a cold first of week. Mrs. Elsie Thornhill came home Thursday after spending the winter with her daughter, Mrs. Elsie Weidman in Con necticut. Mrs. Tom Davidson And Judson and Mrs. Crawford Davidson went to see Mrs. Horsley Sunday afternoon.
